paper_title.en: The development of children's understanding of mathematical patterns through mathematical activities
paper_title.ja: The development of children’s understanding of mathematical patterns through mathematical activities

description.en: In this paper we report how children (aged 8) developed their mathematical understanding through number tasks based on the Fibonacci sequence (Bamboo numbers) used in the context of a Substantial Learning Environment (SLE), which is designed to be mathematically rich, have a clear purpose and give opportunities to utilise mathematical thinking. The flexible nature of the SLEs makes it possible for teachers and children to explore various mathematical patterns. To capture children's activities when working within SLEs, we make particular reference to Pegg and Tall's work in 2005, and consider a theoretical framework based on the SOLO taxonomy (Biggs and Collis 1982) and the developmental process of understanding mathematical concepts. It was found that the key progression to be made through learning using our Bamboo number-based SLEs is from Multi-structural to Relational levels. It was also suggested that it is difficult for many children to understand the structural aspects of number patterns. © 2011 British Society for Research into Learning Mathematics.

paper_title.en: The Influence of "Meraner Vorschlage" (1905) on Japanese Mathematics Education : Teaching of the Concept of Function in M. Kuroda's Geometry Textbook (1916)

description.ja: Minoru Kuroda (1871-1922), who introduced the new theory of mathematics education in western countries to the society of mathematics education in Japan since 1913, wrote a new type of textbook for geometry of secondary schools in 1916. Kinnosuke Ogura (1885-1962) who was a pioneer of the historical study of mathematics education in Japan said that his textbook was influenced by mathematics education in western countries at the beginning of 20^<the> century. However little is known about what idea Kuroda picked up from mathematics education in western countries. The purpose of this paper is to examine what influence was exercised on Kuroda's textbook. The author compared Kuroda's textbook with "Meraner Vorschlage" (1905) that was a new mathematics curriculum made by "die Gesellschaft Duetscher Naturforscher and Arzte" in Germany. One of the findings that were obtained through the comparison is that both "Meraner Vorschlage" and Kuroda aimed at teaching the concept of function through teaching geometry. In conclusion, Kuroda's geometry textbook (1916) was strongly influenced by "Meraner Vorschlage".
description.en: Minoru Kuroda (1871-1922), who introduced the new theory of mathematics education in western countries to the society of mathematics education in Japan since 1913, wrote a new type of textbook for geometry of secondary schools in 1916. Kinnosuke Ogura (1885-1962) who was a pioneer of the historical study of mathematics education in Japan said that his textbook was influenced by mathematics education in western countries at the beginning of 20^<the> century. However little is known about what idea Kuroda picked up from mathematics education in western countries. The purpose of this paper is to examine what influence was exercised on Kuroda's textbook. The author compared Kuroda's textbook with "Meraner Vorschlage" (1905) that was a new mathematics curriculum made by "die Gesellschaft Duetscher Naturforscher and Arzte" in Germany. One of the findings that were obtained through the comparison is that both "Meraner Vorschlage" and Kuroda aimed at teaching the concept of function through teaching geometry. In conclusion, Kuroda's geometry textbook (1916) was strongly influenced by "Meraner Vorschlage".
